qas.question: If a person has TB that's resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid, which type of the disease do they have?
What's the minimum number of second-line medication classes your TB would have to resist to make it count as "extensively drug-resistant"?
In what country was the first case of totally drug-resistant tuberculosis?
What's the only antibiotic that might be effective against totally drug-resistant TB?
Cases of totally drug-resistant TB have been found in what country in addition to Italy and India?
Someone who is not susceptible to MTP develops what?
What is low-quality medication an example of a lack of?
What was first reported in Iran?

context: Primary resistance occurs when a person becomes infected with a resistant strain of TB. A person with fully susceptible MTB may develop <b5_0>secondary (acquired) resistance<b5_0/> during therapy because of inadequate treatment, not taking the prescribed regimen appropriately (lack of <b6_0>compliance<b6_0/>), or using low-quality medication. Drug-resistant TB is a serious public health issue in many developing countries, as its treatment is longer and requires more expensive drugs. <a0_0>MDR-TB<a0_0/> is defined as resistance to the two most effective first-line TB drugs: rifampicin and isoniazid. Extensively drug-resistant TB is also resistant to <a1_0>three<a1_0/> or more of the six classes of second-line drugs. <b7_0>Totally drug-resistant TB<b7_0/> is resistant to all currently used drugs. It was first observed in <b8_0>2003<b8_0/> in <a2_0><b9_0>Italy<b9_0/><a2_0/>, but not widely reported until 2012, and has also been found in <a4_0>Iran<a4_0/> and India. <a3_0>Bedaquiline<a3_0/> is tentatively supported for use in multiple drug-resistant TB.
